171.text:
You and Patrisse Marie Cullors and Opal Tometi
co-founded #BlackLivesMatter.

176.text:
Who the heck are you, and how did you come
up with [#BlackLivesMatter]?

181.text:
#BlackLivesMatter really started as a love
note to our people in the aftermath of the

190.text:
acquittal of George Zimmerman in the murder
of Trayvon Martin.

193.text:
I know I personally felt like I got punched
in the gut.

197.text:
I have a twenty-five year-old brother who's
six feet tall and has a huge afro and just

202.text: the sweetest person you could ever meet.

205.text:
He's growing up in a predominately white suburban
community, and so was Trayvon, right?

213.text:
He was stalked and killed by an aspiring security
guard who felt that Trayvon didn't belong

219.text:
#BlackLivesMatter was really a response to
some of the responses we were seeing, even

228.text:
We were hearing things like, on the sentence
side, we knew justice was never going to be

236.text:
Living black in America we do know that it's
rare that justice is served for black communities,

241.text: but that didn't feel like the right response.

244.text:
The other thing we were hearing was, "This
is a terrible tragedy, and so what we need

247.text: to do is X, Y and Z."

249.text: X, Y and Z being pull up your pants.

251.text:
X, Y and Z being we need to vote, we need
better education, we need stronger families.

257.text:
All of those things really blame black communities
for our own conditions.

261.text:
#BlackLivesMatter was an attempt for us to
re-humanize us in a world that so profoundly

266.text: dehumanizes us, and it was a call to action.

270.text:
We were able to both, because we're all organizers
and because people like Opal have incredible

276.text:
skills in building online platforms, we were
able to use that to build connections online

282.text: so that people can take action together offline.

For a lot of people, your movement and your

292.text:

how your day-to-day managing and organizing

305.text:
is changing, and some of the things that you

309.text:

and how it really took off is that when Mike

315.text:
Brown was killed in August of 2014, Patrice
and Darnell Moore, who is a scholar, activist

323.text:
here in New York, called for a #BlackLivesMatter

That drew more than five hundred black people
from across the country who in ten days raised

333.text:
the money, got on buses, vans, planes, however
folks could get there, to really support the

339.text:
work that was happening in Ferguson, and also
to bear witness to the incredible Jim Crow

From that ride people got excited about and

they had seen and what they had learned back

by the actions that people were taking on

The ways in which folks there were really

together, knowing that maybe folks hadn't

been connected before, but certainly that

The growth of the project has really been

and a call to re-humanize us around the world,

447.text: Matter, or, I don't know, My Life Matters.

You've written very powerfully about how shedding

459.text:

to All Lives Matter is not an act of solidarity.

466.text:

472.text: When we say All Lives Matter, that's a given.

Of course we're all human beings, we all bleed

lives are valued more than others, and that's

It's about inter-personal dynamics that are
back by systemic power.

When we look at that we see that black people
are on the losing end of every disparity that

531.text:
Not only is it not appropriate to not be paying

Not only are black lives on the receiving

labor was at the heart of the way we created

565.text:
The way that race works in this country is
really on a black to white spectrum.

569.text:
The closer you are to black, the worse off
you are.

When we talk about black liberation being

652.text:

You've touched on it right there, but in terms

659.text:
it all one, or how do these two movements

665.text:
Is it Tuesdays and Wednesdays, or Thursdays

667.text: It's really all the same work.

669.text:
Domestic workers, in particular the work I
do with black domestic workers, are mothers

674.text:
who are trying to protect their families from
state violence.

678.text:
The way that we talk about state violence
with #BlackLivesMatter is that state violence

684.text:
Not only have domestic workers, who are largely
black, been excluded from federal labor protections

691.text:
and now are largely immigrant, but they are
mothers who are living in communities that

696.text:
are being terrorized by unaccountable police
departments.

700.text:
They are mothers who are living in communities
where the schools are failing, where there's

705.text:
a lack of investment, where wages are falling,
where there's high unemployment.

710.text:
These are also folks who are caring for other
people's families, and not having the space

715.text:
or the time or the resources to care for their
own.

718.text:
That has impacts on whether or not their family's
able to survive.

726.text:
The other thing I think is important about
the connection between the two is that it

730.text:
is all about empowering women, women of color,
immigrant women, low-income women.

736.text:
It's about bringing the margins back to the
center to really shape our vision for a new

741.text: economy, a new democracy and a new society.

749.text:
Young, African-American, many of them queer
women, are at the center of of the #BlackLivesMatter

753.text:
movement, not that you would know that from
the media coverage.

Why is it so hard for journalists to tell

768.text:

That's how our homes work, that's how our
